text.title: Unit Eleven: Piacere and Similar Verbs

paragraphs.content: **Piacere** corresponds to ‘to like’, but it is used in a different way from its English counterpart. In Italian, the subject of the verb/sentence is the thing or person one likes; the person who likes something is denoted by an indirect object pronoun (see Unit 10):

**Piacere** is an irregular verb mostly used in the third person singular (**piace**) and plural (**piacciono**). As can be seen in the examples, **piace** is used if the thing that one likes is a singular noun or pronoun, or the infinitive of a verb; **piacciono** is used if the things that one likes are a plural noun or pronoun:
**Mi piacciono i gatti.** (I like cats. [lit. cats are pleasing to me])
The negative is formed by putting **non** before the pronoun:
As usual, for the polite form in the singular the feminine pronoun (**Le**) is used for both men and women; for the plural **Vi** is normally used:
* **Loro** is a much more formal way of addressing people in the plural; it is always placed after the verb.

rows: Do you like mushrooms, Mrs Vanni?
Do you like reading, Mr Vanni?
Do you like Italy, Mr and Mrs Conti?
Do you like Italy, Mr and Mrs Conti?

paragraphs.content: When the person who likes something is denoted not by a pronoun but by a noun, the noun must be preceded by the preposition **a**:

rows: **A Claudia non piace** andare a scuola.
Claudia doesn’t like going to school.
**Allo zio Davide piace** la musica classica.

paragraphs.content: To mark a contrast, the stressed forms of the pronouns (**a me**, **a te**, **a lui**/**a lei**, **a noi**, **a voi**, **a loro** – see Unit 14) are used instead of the unstressed forms:

rows: **A me piace** il tè, **a te piace** il caffè.
I like tea, you like coffee.
**A lui piace** sciare, ma **a lei piace** pattinare.
He likes skiing, but she likes skating.
**A noi piacciono** i film, **a voi piacciono** i libri.
We like films, you like books.

paragraphs.content: There are other verbs which are used in the same way as **piacere**: **mancare** (to miss) [lit. ‘to be lacking/missing’]; **servire** (to need) [lit. ‘to be useful’]; **bastare** (to be enough/sufficient) and **sembrare** and **parere** (to seem):

rows: I miss my family. [lit. My family is lacking to me]
Do you need a pen? [lit. Is a pen useful to you?]
A week of vacation is enough for him. [lit. A week of vacation is sufficient to him]
It seems like a good idea to us.
Does it seem fair to you?

exercises.title: Exercise 1: Replace with Pronouns
exercises.instruction: Rewrite the sentences, replacing the words in italics with the correct pronoun.
examples: **A Claudia non piace** andare a scuola.: **Non le piace** andare a scuola.
**A Franco e Luisa piace** viaggiare.: **Gli piace** viaggiare.

items.question: **A Tullio e Anna piace** il mare.
**A me e a Marco non piace** il pesce.
**A te e a Marina piace** nuotare?

exercises.title: Exercise 2: Negative Sentences
exercises.instruction: Change the sentences into the negative.
examples: **Le piace** andare in centro il sabato.: **Non le piace** andare in centro il sabato.
**Ti piace** la musica classica?: **Non ti piace** la musica classica?

items.question: **Le piace** andare in centro il sabato.
items.answer: Non le piace andare in centro il sabato.

items.question: **Ti piace** la musica classica?
items.answer: Non ti piace la musica classica?

items.question: **Vi piace** guardare la televisione?
items.answer: Non vi piace guardare la televisione?

items.question: **Mi piacciono** i film di fantascienza.
items.answer: Non mi piacciono i film di fantascienza.

items.question: **Ci piacciono** le canzoni italiane.
items.answer: Non ci piacciono le canzoni italiane.

items.question: **Vi piace** la cioccolata al latte?
items.answer: Non vi piace la cioccolata al latte?

exercises.title: Exercise 3: Express Your Taste
exercises.instruction: Write sentences expressing your taste using **piacere**. Use affirmative or negative as you prefer.

exercises.title: Exercise 4: Make Sentences
exercises.instruction: Make sentences using the verb **piacere** and the prompts given.
examples: mio fratello / la pizza: **A mio fratello piace** la pizza.
i miei amici / sciare: **Ai miei amici piace** sciare.

items.question: mio fratello / la pizza
items.answer: A mio fratello piace la pizza.

items.question: mia sorella / andare al cinema
items.answer: A mia sorella piace andare al cinema.

items.question: i miei cugini / i film di Fellini
items.answer: Ai miei cugini piacciono i film di Fellini.

items.question: il primo ministro / la politica
items.answer: Al primo ministro piace la politica.

exercises.title: Exercise 5: Supply Verb Forms
exercises.instruction: Supply the correct form of the verbs in brackets.
examples: **Vi (sembrare)** bello quel film?: **Vi sembra** bello quel film?

items.question: **A Livio (mancare)** i soldi per le vacanze.
items.answer: A Livio mancano i soldi per le vacanze.

items.question: **Quello che dici mi (sembrare)** interessante.
items.answer: Quello che dici mi sembra interessante.

items.question: **Quale di quei due libri ti (parere)** migliore?
items.answer: Quale di quei due libri ti pare migliore?

exercises.title: Exercise 6: Translate into Italian
exercises.instruction: Translate into Italian, using the verbs **piacere**, **sembrare**, **servire**, **mancare**, or **bastare**.
examples: An hour isn’t enough for me!: **Non mi basta** un’ora!
Giovanni needs a pen.: **A Giovanni serve** una penna.

items.question: An hour isn’t enough for me!
Lynne’s missing her Italian friends.
items.answer: A Lynne mancano i suoi amici italiani.

items.question: She doesn’t like going to the cinema.
items.answer: Non le piace andare al cinema.

items.question: They need a pen and a notebook.
items.answer: Gli servono una penna e un quaderno.

items.question: Do you find the show boring, Madam?
items.answer: Le sembra noioso lo spettacolo, Signora?
